title: What happens when the ozone layer is damaged? - Quora

response.answer_text: What happens when the ozone layer is damaged? Ozone in the upper atmosphere serves to absorb ultraviolet light from the sun. This is important to us and many other life-forms because UV light causes sunburn and skin cancer. When the ozone in the upper atmosphere is broken down by some of the chemicals that we emit, it changes into a form that no longer blocks UV. For various complicated reasons, so far, our damage has been limited to the areas above the North and South poles…and not much lives in those places, so it hasn’t caused too many horrendous side-effects. But we have to be careful with substances such as chloroflorocarbon that are notorious at destroying ozone. Ozone is actually just oxygen. Normal oxygen molecules have two atoms bound together - that’s the oxygen we breathe down here at ground level. But up in the upper atmosphere, oxygen can be bound into molecules with THREE atoms together - and that’s what we call “ozone”. This isn’t a very stable molecule - and it doesn’t take much to make it convert back into regular two-atom oxygen - which doesn’t absorb UV light so well. Ozone is not good stuff to breathe - so it’s fortunate that it mostly only exists at very high altitudes. Here at ground level, there are processes that create ozone - lightning storms and electrical arcs being good examples. That tangy smell in the air after a big storm - or if something makes a big spark for some reason - that’s ozone.
